 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.

If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and
your contract.

questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone

ALLEGATION:
Staff was bitten by a resident. When staff was bitten, she jumped up and extended
her arm and resident was pushed to the floor.
2

INVESTIGATION:
On 8/12/2020 I received an online complaint allegation that Staff 1 was bitten by
Resident A. When bitten, Staff 1 jumped up and extended her arm, pushing
Resident A to the floor. Resident A was checked for marks and none were found.
Interviews
On 8/12/2020 I sent an email to DHHS Worker 1 to inform her of the investigation.
She informed me that Resident A is mostly non-verbal and wouldn’t be able to tell
me about the incident.
On 8/17/2020 I made an unannounced visit to the facility and explained the
investigation allegations to the Chief Administrator. Chief Administrator stated that
she was aware of the incident and stated that she has had no other issues or
concerns with Staff 1. While at the facility, I interviewed Staff 1 who reported that, on
8/9/2020, she was eating her dinner on a couch in the milieu area. Resident A was
upset and swearing because he wanted Staff 1 to put him to bed even though she
wasn’t his primary staff that day, so he kneeled on the floor by Staff 1 and bit her
shin area. Staff 1 responded by immediately pulling her leg back and extending her
right arm to “put space” between them. When she extended her arm, she made
contact with Resident A. He fell backward and started yelling at Staff 1 for pushing
him. Staff 1 stated that she is unsure if she pushed Resident A or if he was being
dramatic, as he often is with her. Staff 1 stated that she checked Resident A and
didn’t see any bruising or injuries, talked to him about what happened, then put him
to bed.
After interviewing Staff 1, I observed Resident A in his bedroom getting ready for his
day.
On 8/24/2020 I interviewed Staff 2 and Staff 3 by phone. Staff 2 reported that she
saw Resident A run up and bite Staff 1 on the leg and Staff 1, without even looking
at Resident A, pushed him away. Staff 2 stated that it looked like an automatic
response and that Staff 1 didn’t intend to push Resident A down. She stated that
Resident A then “flopped” on the floor “dramatically” and called Staff 1 names. Staff
2 reported that the staff are trained to initiate a bite release if a resident latches on,
but this bite didn’t look that hard. Staff 3 stated that she was working at the time of
the incident but did not see the bite or push.
Documents Reviewed
On 8/12/2020 I received an incident report dated 8/10/2020, which was written by
Staff 1 and documented the details of the incident as provided in her interview.
On 8/17/2020 I received and reviewed the Satori study guide section regarding bite
protection procedures.
3

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4157 Behavior management.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that describe the
institution’s behavior management system. The
policies and procedures shall be reviewed annually
and updated as needed. These shall be available to
all residents, their families, and referring agencies.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1 did not follow the policies and procedures regarding
behavior management when she extended her arm and pushed
a resident who had bitten her.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
Agency policies and procedures regarding incident reporting were not followed.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews
On 8/12/2020 I sent an email to DHHS Worker 1 to inform her of an investigation
regarding Resident A. She replied on 8/13/2020 stating that she was not notified of
the incident by the facility staff.
On 8/17/2020 I interviewed Staff 1 in person. She reported that she has worked at
the facility for 14 years and hasn’t filled out an incident report in the last 7 years. She
stated that she must have just forgotten to notify the worker of the incident.
Documents Reviewed
On 8/12/2020 I received and reviewed an Incident Report (IR) written by Staff 1 on
8/10/2020. According to the IR, the incident took place on 8/9/2020. The section of
the report in which notification to the resident’s caseworker is to be documented was
blank.
On 8/17/2020 I received and reviewed a copy of the facility’s incident reporting policy
which states that incident reports are to be completed prior to the end of the shift
during which the incident occurred. I also received and reviewed the incident
reporting requirement policy which states that any diversion from the approved
behavior management technique must be reported.
4

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1 did not follow the established policies and procedures
regarding incident reporting when she failed to complete an
incident report prior to the end of the shift during which it
occurred and forgetting to notify the resident’s assigned
caseworker.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend no change to status of this license upon receipt of an acceptable CAP.
